narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Reading, writing, and oral skills definitely improved. There's a major emphasis on conversation, so I had to step out of my comfort level a bit, but Yelsy was extremely supportive and welcoming!
Spanish language speaking, listening, writing and reading comprehension
How to speak and write better Spanish
Advanced Spanish conversational grammar and skills
increased ability to speak and understand Spanish; more practice reading and writing

Developed speaking, writing, reading, and listening skills in spanish
Learned about history and politics in spanish-speaking countries
Had very critical conversations about current events in spanish

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths
-high engagement
-lots of breakout rooms
-respectable amount of work
-amazing prof
weaknesses
-final two weeks were extremely stressful (oral exam, composition, and exam were all within the span of a week)
Fun class but way too many assignments.

Strengths: daily lessons to strengthen Spanish skills. Conversations in class

Weaknesses: zoom

Strengths: 
- Canvas was well-organized (assignments were relatively easy to locate) and it was really nice that the weightings of the different categories were put into Canvas so the grade on Canvas actually matched up with the grade in the course
- assignments (and classroom activities) facilitated practice in reading, listening, writing, and speaking in Spanish

Weakness: 
- the only real complaint I have is the fact that we had two assessments very close to the end of the semester (Exam 3 and the oral exam), but neither one was scheduled during finals week, and the oral exam was even scheduled during reading period. This made the end of the semester more stressful than it would have been if one of those assessments was simply placed during finals week

Could have given us feedback before participation grades came out
Some of the exams could have been more spaced out, but other than that this course was very engaging and open to the learning process
Developed speaking, writing, reading, and listening skills in spanish
Learned about history and politics in spanish-speaking countries
Had very critical conversations about current events in spanish

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtually the class was fine.

I think online language learning is inherently less natural than in-person language learning, but I think the professor did an admirable job facilitating a language-learning experience. Breakout rooms were used frequently and effectively. I can't think of any specific online procedure that was significantly underwhelming.

Very understanding of difficulties during the pandemic
Some of the exams could have been more spaced out

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Reading, writing, and oral skills definitely improved. There's a major emphasis on conversation, so I had to step out of my comfort level a bit, but Yelsy was extremely supportive and welcoming!
Yes, but I would warn them that it is a lot of work.

Yes, I would recommend it. I also would caution that, in regards to practice speaking, you really get as much out of this course as you put into it. For example, someone who volunteers to participate in class frequently will get more speaking practice, and thus likely see a greater improvement in their skills, than someone who rarely volunteers to participate. Overall, I think this class is a great way to hone your reading, writing (especially this one), speaking, and listening skills in Spanish. It is a lot of work though.

Yes!
Very engaging and open to the learning process
Developed speaking, writing, reading, and listening skills in spanish
Learned about history and politics in spanish-speaking countries
Had very critical conversations about current events in spanish
Very passionate about our conversations, created a great learning environment

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Breakout rooms
also optional office hours
Acted as both a lecture (when teaching spanish concepts) and also discussion-oriented to help us learn how to speak
